item.title: Californians Talk HIV: Using Social Media to Get Steps Ahead
item.description: Multidisciplinary project with public health and computer science researchers from the University of California San Diego and the Johns Hopkins University. The goal of the project is to develop automated methods to extract actionable intelligence from social media platforms to support timely, evidence-based decision making and help public health leaders and advocates stay one step ahead of Californiaâ€™s HIV epidemic.

item.title: Increasing Citizen Participation in E-Rulemaking by Harnessing Social Media
item.description: Multidisciplinary project with public health and computer science researchers from University of California San Diego and the Johns Hopkins University, aiming to increase public participation in the regulatory process by crowdsourcing and extracting actionable feedback regarding government regulations from public social media comments.

item.title: REACTION
item.description:
Retrieval, Extraction and Aggregation Computing Technology for Integrating and Organizing News

Interdisciplinary R&D project, funded by the CoLab, UT Austin - Portugal, involving researchers from the Faculdade de CiÃªncias da Universidade de Lisboa, INESC-ID Lisboa, Faculdade de Engenharia da Universidade do Porto, Centro de InvestigacÌ§aÌƒo Media e Jornalismo, University of Texas at Austin and news media partners such as Sapo and PÃºblico to create tools and methodologies to support advanced computational newsrooms.

We developed novel data-driven tools for journalists to gain new insights into complex topics — e.g. our tools were used in an article about political campaign financing that won a cyber journalism award. We also developed various tools for journalists to use social media to track media personalities over time, gauge public reactions to newsworthy events, and analyse global events in real-time.

See the project’s (archived) webpage for more details and the respective scoop.it for some of the related press coverage.
